item.title: [PI] Random tip on login [PI]
item.dc:creator: @relexlawl relexlawl
item.description:
@relexlawl wrote:

[quote=“blackflag_, post:24, topic:461329”][quote author=relexlawl link=topic=564262.msg4108793#msg4108793 date=1348326107]
Or you could do:

[code] private static final String[] LOGIN_TIP = {“tormented demons drop dragon claws?”, “you can make money by skilling and selling to shops?”};

private static void tips(Client client) {
	String tip = LOGIN_TIP[(int) (Math.random() * (LOGIN_TIP.length - 1))];
	client.sendMessage("Did you know " + tip);
}[/code]

[/quote]

[code]
Random random = new Random();

    private static final String[] LOGIN_TIP = {"tormented demons drop dragon claws?", "you can make money by skilling and selling to shops?"};

private static void tips(Client client) {
	String tip = LOGIN_TIP[random.nextInt(LOGIN_TIP.length)];
	client.sendMessage("Did you know " + tip);
}[/code][/quote]

Believe someone has already talked about micro-optimizations…

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] Random tip on login [PI]
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:4, topic:461329”] private static final String[] LOGIN_TIP = {"tormented demons drop dragon claws", "you can make money by skilling and selling to shops"}; private static void tips(Client client) { client.sendMessage("Did you know " + LOGIN_TIP[(int) (Math.random() * (LOGIN_TIP.length - 1))] + "?"); }

Even better[/quote]
Uses a few extra instructions to append the ‘?’ at the end. Quit micro-optimizing for shit code.

[quote=“Ambokile, post:10, topic:461329”]Mine creates two string objects (well, multiple in the array but let’s say thats one, and then it creates another in sendMessage. Yours creates three (“one” in the array, another in the method and then another in the sendMessage method.)
Therefore, my question (“why create another string object”) was right[/quote]
The instance is already created in . When accessing it in the array it creates a new pointer and stores it in the local var table, it doesn’t create a new instance. Please stop micro-optimizing, especially when you don’t understand the bytecode!

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] Random tip on login [PI]
item.dc:creator: @relexlawl relexlawl
item.description:
@relexlawl wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:10, topic:461329”][quote author=relexlawl link=topic=564262.msg4111152#msg4111152 date=1348526512]

private static final String[] LOGIN_TIP = {"tormented demons drop dragon claws", "you can make money by skilling and selling to shops"}; private static void tips(Client client) { client.sendMessage("Did you know " + LOGIN_TIP[(int) (Math.random() * (LOGIN_TIP.length - 1))] + "?"); }

Even better

Relex’s is cleaner.

Cleaner but why create another String object when it’s not needed?

It’s only creating the String once…Then it’s just calling on it…honestly if you don’t know what you’re talking about, why… just never mind…
[/quote]

Mine creates two string objects (well, multiple in the array but let’s say thats one, and then it creates another in sendMessage. Yours creates three (“one” in the array, another in the method and then another in the sendMessage method.)
Therefore, my question (“why create another string object”) was right[/quote]

Are you serious?..my god…

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] Random tip on login [PI]
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“relexlawl, post:9, topic:461329”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=564262.msg4110643#msg4110643 date=1348468466]

private static final String[] LOGIN_TIP = {"tormented demons drop dragon claws", "you can make money by skilling and selling to shops"}; private static void tips(Client client) { client.sendMessage("Did you know " + LOGIN_TIP[(int) (Math.random() * (LOGIN_TIP.length - 1))] + "?"); }

Even better

Relex’s is cleaner.

Cleaner but why create another String object when it’s not needed?
[/quote]

It’s only creating the String once…Then it’s just calling on it…honestly if you don’t know what you’re talking about, why… just never mind…[/quote]

Mine creates two string objects (well, multiple in the array but let’s say thats one, and then it creates another in sendMessage. Yours creates three (“one” in the array, another in the method and then another in the sendMessage method.)
Therefore, my question (“why create another string object”) was right

Read full topic
